dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Over 500 companies have now joined this Facebook ad boycott, which is just staggering.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Over five hundred companies have now joined this Facebook ad boycott, which is just staggering.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With over 500 companies having now joined the advertising boycott of Facebook called for by top civil rights groups, some investors are concerned about the companys lost revenuebut most Wall Street firms estimate that Facebook is still looking at less than a 5% hit to overall revenue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it includes some huge names, like Pfizer, Lego, Dunkin' Donuts... but the analysts are saying the financial hit might not be as bad as it seems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it includes some huge names, like Pfizer, Lego, Dunkin' Donuts... but the analysts are saying the financial hit might not be as bad as it seems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook shares initially plunged by 8% last Friday amid an increasing number of big brandsmost recently joined by Pfizer, Lego and Dunkin Donutsannouncing that they will stop working with the tech giant as part of the #StopHateforProfits campaign, which has now grown to include more than 500 advertisers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, MKM Partners analyst Rohit Kulkarni estimates it's looking at less than a 5% hit to overall revenue. That's the key number here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, M K M Partners analyst Rohit Kulkarni estimates it's looking at less than a five percent hit to overall revenue. That's the key number here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook is looking at a less than 5% hit to its overall revenue, said Rohit Kulkarni, an analyst for MKM Partners, in a recent note.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which, for a company that size, is uh, relatively manageable in the short term. Morgan Stanley even broke it down—losing the top 100 advertisers might only be about a billion dollars a month.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, for a company that size, is uh, relatively manageable in the short term. Morgan Stanley even broke it down-losing the top one hundred advertisers might only be about a billion dollars a month.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a scenario where the company loses business from its top 100 advertisers, that would only be around a $1 billion hit to revenue per month, Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak estimates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A billion dollars sounds enormous, but for Facebook's scale? It's a dent, not a disaster. And if the boycott only lasts a month, Citi says the stock impact could be as low as one dollar per share.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A billion dollars sounds enormous, but for Facebook's scale? It's a dent, not a disaster. And if the boycott only lasts a month, Citi says the stock impact could be as low as one dollar per share.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If the ad boycott only lasts one month, according to Citi analysts, the likely impact on Facebooks stock is just $1 per share, and if Facebook is unable to convince the companies who are boycotting to resume business, the impact on its stock would be $17 per share, they estimate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild though, because the campaign is called #StopHateForProfit, right? So it's a moral stance, but the financial pressure might not be enough to force real change.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild though, because the campaign is called #StopHateForProfit, right? So it's a moral stance, but the financial pressure might not be enough to force real change.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook shares initially plunged by 8% last Friday amid an increasing number of big brandsmost recently joined by Pfizer, Lego and Dunkin Donutsannouncing that they will stop working with the tech giant as part of the #StopHateforProfits campaign, which has now grown to include more than 500 advertisers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And Kulkarni pointed out that their revenue base is incredibly diverse—millions of advertisers. Even a giant like Procter & Gamble is less than half a percent of their total ad revenue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And Kulkarni pointed out that their revenue base is incredibly diverse-millions of advertisers. Even a giant like Procter and Gamble is less than half a percent of their total ad revenue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Advertisers were already winding down spending amid the coronavirus pandemic, Kulkarni notes, but Facebook has a diverse revenue base, with millions of paying advertisers; Procter & Gamble, for example, is the largest advertiser in the world but is estimated to account for less than 0.50% of Facebooks revenues, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So the message from Wall Street seems to be, uh, 'this hurts, but it's not catastrophic.' The stock did plunge initially, but the buy ratings are mostly holding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the message from Wall Street seems to be, uh, 'this hurts, but it's not catastrophic.' The stock did plunge initially, but the buy ratings are mostly holding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Facebook shares initially plunged by 8% last Friday amid an increasing number of big brandsmost recently joined by Pfizer, Lego and Dunkin Donutsannouncing that they will stop working with the tech giant as part of the #StopHateforProfits campaign, which has now grown to include more than 500 advertisers. But Wall Street firms generally remain quite bullish on the stock, with the large majority reiterating buy ratings: Facebook is looking at a less than 5% hit to its overall revenue, said Rohit Kulkarni, an analyst for MKM Partners, in a recent note.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It really highlights how entrenched they are. Advertisers might pause, but where else are they gonna go to reach that audience?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really highlights how entrenched they are. Advertisers might pause, but where else are they gonna go to reach that audience?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's the uncomfortable truth of it. The platform's reach is just too massive to ignore for long.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's the uncomfortable truth of it. The platform's reach is just too massive to ignore for long.

artist_script:
IN A WALL STREET ANALYSIS FIRM, MID-JULY.
HostA: Over 500 companies have now joined this Facebook ad boycott, which is just staggering.
HostB: Yeah, and it includes some huge names, like Pfizer, Lego, Dunkin' Donuts... but the analysts are saying the financial hit might not be as bad as it seems.
HostA: Right, MKM Partners analyst Rohit Kulkarni estimates it's looking at less than a 5% hit to overall revenue. That's the key number here.
HostB: Which, for a company that size, is uh, relatively manageable in the short term. Morgan Stanley even broke it down—losing the top 100 advertisers might only be about a billion dollars a month.
HostA: A billion dollars sounds enormous, but for Facebook's scale? It's a dent, not a disaster. And if the boycott only lasts a month, Citi says the stock impact could be as low as one dollar per share.
HostB: It's wild though, because the campaign is called #StopHateForProfit, right? So it's a moral stance, but the financial pressure might not be enough to force real change.
HostA: Exactly. And Kulkarni pointed out that their revenue base is incredibly diverse—millions of advertisers. Even a giant like Procter & Gamble is less than half a percent of their total ad revenue.
HostB: So the message from Wall Street seems to be, uh, 'this hurts, but it's not catastrophic.' The stock did plunge initially, but the buy ratings are mostly holding.
HostA: It really highlights how entrenched they are. Advertisers might pause, but where else are they gonna go to reach that audience?
HostB: Yeah, that's the uncomfortable truth of it. The platform's reach is just too massive to ignore for long.
